Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification requirements. Exemption from notification requirements for state and local political committees under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include political committees of state or local candidates and state or local committees of political parties. The amendments take effect retroactively as if included in Public Law 106-230. Exemption for state and local political committees from reporting requirements. Mandatory exceptions apply to certain organizations. Certain organizations are exempt from filing annual returns if they fall under specific categories such as State or local political committees, caucuses, authorized committees of candidates for Federal office, or national committees of political parties. Certain organizations exempt from filing annual returns include national committees of political parties, US House or Senate campaign committees, political committees required to report under the Federal Election Campaign Act, and organizations subject to section 527 solely due to subsection (f)(1). The Secretary has discretionary authority to grant exceptions. The Secretary may exempt organizations from filing information returns if deemed unnecessary for tax law administration. Effective Dates:
- Subsections (a) and (b) apply to failures after enactment.
- Subsection (c) is effective as if included in Public Law 106-230.
- Subsection (d) applies to reports and notices after enactment.
- Subsections (e)(1) and (f) apply to reports and notices. The amendments made by subsections (e)(1) and (f) apply to reports and notices filed more than 30 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by subsections (e)(2) and (e)(3) apply to reports filed on or after June 30, 2003. The amendments made by subsection (g) apply to material changes on or after the enactment of the Act. The transition rule for material changes under the Act states that a notice under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code is not required to be filed within 30 days after the material change or 45 days after the enactment of the Act. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of the Internal Revenue Code.
